Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Defining and Measuring University Economic Engagement: The Association of Public and Land Grant Universities Innovation and Economic Prosperity (APLU-IEP) Data Platform

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Association of Public and Land-grant Universities (APLU) has offered a voluntary program to encourage university community engagement since 2012. To participate in the APLU program, universities conduct an intensive self-study process that results previously unavailable information. The program has amassed applications containing descriptive information about the structures, processes, and outputs of university economic engagement. These application documents represent a valuable source of information to help us better understand how universities engage with their communities to foster economic prosperity, how they view their role in their innovation ecosystems and how they measure their progress in economic engagement. Defining, measuring and advancing university economic engagement is a potentially transformative research initiative for moving forward science and innovation policy that will result in a wide-range of regional and national societal benefits.

This project makes the APLU community engagement information readily accessible to researchers. The collection of application documents will be converted into a coherent, well-structured dataset that is easy to access and conducive to further qualitative and quantitative research explorations. The project identifies broad data trends and types of metrics used by universities to assess engagement. This effort will leverage this rich data to advance our knowledge and understanding, and spur potentially transformative research in university economic engagement.

Institution.Name: The University of Central Florida Board of Trustees
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CENTRAL FLORIDA BOARD OF TRUSTEES, THE

Performance_Institution.Name: The University of Central Florida Board of Trustees

POR.DRECONTENT:
Universities are an engine of economic growth that contribute to social and economic development in several ways including through building talent, setting up foundations for discovery and innovation, developing knowledge through cutting edge research, and fostering economic engagement through society and industry partnerships. Although, there are many studies that report activities and achievements from various universities across several dimensions of economic engagement, more research is needed to identify reliable strategies for improving university economic engagement. A better understanding of these strategies would support the development of best practices for improving university economic engagement. In addition, there is a need for a comparative study to identify appropriate metrics and further refine the evaluation of economic engagement across universities.

 

The Association of Public and Land-grant Universities (APLU) offers an Innovation and Economic Prosperity (IEP) designation to universities that demonstrate excellence in economic and community engagement. Member universities submit self-study reports to the APLU to receive this designation, which provides a rich source of evidence regarding the activities that these universities engage in to improve their economic engagement. However, this data is in the form of narratives and is difficult to interpret and utilize for advanced research. Therefore, the purpose of this research is to analyze the evidence in the data corpus to synthesize the available data and identify strategies used by these universities to advance their economic engagement. This study investigates the APLU IEP Universities data corpus to identify trends that support the development of best practices for improving university economic engagement.

 

Three main goals were defined for this study. First, processing the IEP Universities data so that it is more readily accessible to researchers by converting the IEP University collection of application documents into a coherent, well-organized, well-structured, annotated and documented dataset that is easy to access, easy to use, and conducive to further qualitative and quantitative research. Second, identify broad data trends and insights that can be used to setup follow-on research by identifying the kind of research questions that could be pursued with this dataset as well as key data points and trends meriting further study. Third, identify types of metrics used by universities to assess their self-reported economic prosperity strengths and weaknesses.

 

The results of this study show that there are six dimensions of economic engagement reported by the IEP universities: industry partnerships, community engagement, innovation and entrepreneurship programs, commercialization, and technology transfer. This study provides valuable evidence-based data for informing policy decisions on how best to transition from a research and teaching institution to an entrepreneurial university that is innovation-driven.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 12/26/2018
Modified by: Ivan I Garibay
